Flavor.Value: Supply chains have been crushed, and the kingdom's river of goods run dry.
Some say that the origins of this potion lead back to a goblin alchemist and that the recipe was stolen by the human kingdom of Delvemore.

Description.Value: Increased move, attack, and throw speed

ExtendedDescription.Value: A key to a hidden prison cell

ExtendedFlavor.Value: After being caught worshiping a false god by the king's inquisitors, Lillyth was imprisoned in the Delvemore Dungeon. She was deemed too dangerous for normal confinement, so she was locked away on a subfloor and given a personal guard detail.

Description.Value: A key to something better left forgotten

Flavor.Value: The key whispers to you: "there is no room for false gods."
The items have been preserved in thick crystal with the expectations they will be worth something someday.

Description.Value: Bombs brand enemies for sacrifice, +10 bombs

Flavor.Value: "You have now been marked with the brand of sacrifice. The lives of those who bear the brand will be consumed."
The axe is voracious and aggressively seeks new blood.

Description.Value: Increase swing damage, throw size, and throw speed

Flavor.Value: While a monarchy by definition has a single ruler, the King and Queen are two halves of a whole.

ExplanationLocID.Value:
Hexes are powerful, indestructible curses that offer the ultimate challenge for those who seek exceptional difficulty.

They are entirely optional and not for the faint of heart!

Flavor.Value: Invoked by the Crone
A morbid vest made from the flayed hide of a rockpile mimic.

ExtendedDescription.Value: An enchanted journal

ExtendedFlavor.Value: A blank journal enchanted by Arkanos. It automatically inscribes everything its bearer senses, so there is no need to put pen to paper. It is passed on to new peasants by the canary along with the goldsack. This way peasants can know what their predecessors witnessed, and maybe not share in their fate.

Flavor.Value: Press @{system_select} to open the Journal
A simple, but expertly crafted glass bottle. Perfectly suited to carrying brews of all types.

Description.Value: Duplicate all gold in the room

Flavor.Value: A vial of golden popcorn kernels. They vibrate with anticipation.

Description.Value: Bombs explode in a shower of fire

Flavor.Value: Blood of the salamander. Kept only in check, by the blood of her brother.

Description.Value: Gain temporary damage when picking up gold

Flavor.Value: Do not underestimate the lengths one will go to defend their fortune.
A bottle containing one Hoarding Pilfer, dozens of axe pommels, and countless smooth rocks.

Description.Value: Reduces throw damage and increases swing damage

Flavor.Value: A short blade of legend, wielded by the brother. What it lacked in reach, it made up for in power.

Description.Value: Sometimes release a spray of daggers when you throw

Flavor.Value: A devious contraption, invented by a woman who once killed a king. It took the guards an entire hour to figure out what had happened.
The Metamorphim change is a five step process. Mighty Metamorphim combines those into a single, more efficient process.

DeathFlavor.Value: Regrets opening the chest with the teeth.
Knew in his heart opening the chest was a mistake.

Flavor.Value: Now that it has been discovered that mimics can take more than one form there has been a rush to study why they choose the forms they do. Unfortunately no academics return from the UnderMine, making data collection quite difficult. Perhaps in the future there will be a new market for information collection on these and other dangerous creatures.

Description.Value: Free food at the shop, right now!

Flavor.Value: Illegible due to indiscernible scribbles, but has a crude drawing of a sandwich.
The powder has been soaked in Transmutagen, causing anything caught in the blast to be violently changed.
Alchemists took the liquefied remains of the lightning mite and weaponized it... even more so.

The Fire Thrower was invented in a joint effort between the kingdom's engineer guild and the arcane sanctum. A combination of human ingenuity and enchantment brings forth the pinnacle of dungeon security. These devices can distinguish between intruders, critters, and dungeon guards. They occasionally make mistakes, but at an acceptable threshold.

Description.Value: Lock costs are converted to health

Flavor.Value: In the catacombs many walls have shallow ruts in the shape of a hand, and dozens of spines facing outwards at the base of those ruts.
Rook one upped his brother by finding a fifty eighth ingredient.

Description.Value: Consumes 25% health, drops items and sometimes another Blood Chalice

Flavor.Value: A golden goblet with flecks of crimson. It rewards those willing to pay a sacrifice.

Description.Value: Enemies hit with the thrown pickaxe take more damage

Flavor.Value: Pain and misery ooze from the cracks of this dark orb.
Attacking someone with a stone hammer is a crime of war in some kingdoms.
Few can afford the cost of a nobel's head, but that of a lowborne? A price many can pay.
Razzil, the Alchemist finally stabilized his brew and the results are good.
A well worn bag, full of bombs, and covered in black powder.
It is difficult to do anything when the body is unsteady.

Description.Value: Deal more swing damage at high health

Flavor.Value: An award for courage, and a symbol of valor.
The Miracle Berry is the result of decades of research by the alchemists of Delvemore laboratories.

Countless tunnels link Ponzu with the scales he has shed. This network allows each individual scale to act as one more sensory organ for the creature. Ponzu, the scales, and the tunnels are as one and it would be dangerous to treat them otherwise.
If things go poorly in the mine find a bear den and try and blend in.
Peering into the bottle reveals a vortex of fireballs, writhing in furor.

Description.Value: A pilfer trapped in manifested corruption

Flavor.Value: The bog was once a peaceful refuge for the creatures known as pilfers. Gold was unknown to them and they lived a carefree existence, free of predators. Eventually greed and corruption seeped into their culture, and a hierarchy began to form. As the corruption spread, pilfers were consumed by it, and at one point there was no turning back. A bloody civil war sprang forth, and the pilfers have warred against one another ever since.

Description.Value: An unstable formation with sharp edges

Flavor.Value: These rocks form naturally in walls and floor of the typically silent Shimmering Caverns. They grow large spines of crystal. Behind these spines, a harder rock builds up and applies outwards force. Any rumble, or large noise often destabilizes them, allowing for the pressure to fling the spines outwards like projectiles.
"You can't always get what you want. But if you try sometimes, you might just find, you get it for free." - Proverb
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
Sometimes called "searing hot pain."
A cosmic sword, lightning the night's sky with karmic justice.
Peasants are issued one pair of boots a year. The boots never last an entire year.

Description.Value: Removes a curse after defeating enemies and stores it for later
Attacks enemies with a deadly beam
Dark Light penetrates enemies and scales in damage and size for each eaten curse

Flavor.Value: Lesser demons lack the immense power of their greater cousins, but don't make the mistake of thinking they're toothless.

Description.Value: Floors no longer have relic rooms

Flavor.Value: "What do you do when the glittery trinkets are taken away, and are left to rely on your skill alone?" - Valeen, the Crone
Every miner reaches an age when they consider hanging up their pickaxe.
A big fad during the Enlightenment was to have a replica chest in a bottle on your bookshelf.

Description.Value: Double the level of a random blessing

Flavor.Value: Actually a very secular drink, made with blended grass and orange juice.
Appears to be a food sack with three holes cut out of it. Durable, but very itchy.

Description.Value: All enemies are turned to gold

Flavor.Value: A label affixed to the bottom reads: "Warning: Do not ingest."
A contraption that allows the wearer to skip forward in time unbeknownst to others.

Description.Value: Enemies have double health and damage

Flavor.Value: A mist winds its way through the Undermine. It breathes deadly life into the hollow's inhabitants.

Not a lot is known of Glimmerweed since they live so deep in the UnderMine. Very few samples have been recovered for study, and those that return with samples often suffer severe injuries. 

What is known, is that Glimmerweed has a very narrow field of vision, and can mostly see in light and shadow. When enough light is blocked, the weed senses a threat and attacks.

Description.Value: Sometimes drop golden meat from your enemies

Flavor.Value: Much luckier than a Four Leaf Clover.  Much deadlier too.

Description.Value: Increases the cost of shop items

Flavor.Value: The relationship with the Pilfers is tenuous and fickle. Scorn them and suffer the consequences.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

DeathFlavor.Value: Pelted to death by a fly.
Destroyed by a tiny fly.

Description.Value: A fly that attacks in barrages

Flavor.Value: A larger, but slower cousin of the spate fly. Treble flies prefer cooler climates, so they are often found lower in the UnderMine. They defend their territory by firing a trio of shells at their enemies.
Steel-toed and steel-soled, not to be confused with Toadvine, the Steel-Souled Steel-Toad.

Description.Value: Gain two points of armor, armor increases damage

Flavor.Value: Barbarians lack defensive discipline, but they make up for it with offensive prowess.
Item shapes shift and morph like an ephemeral haze. Their form eludes the senses, as if the eyes and ears cannot focus.
A little pine tar for that extra zip.
The barbs are sharp and cruel. They dig into flesh and cloth alike.
This potion was created at the request of a very wealthy lord who wanted to hide his vast fortune.

Description.Value: Pull the heavens down onto your foes

Flavor.Value: A stern warning adorns the bottle: "More than a sip may cause extinction!"

Description.Value: Store a piece of food for later

Flavor.Value: The best time of day is midday when the pickaxes are down and the sandwiches are up.

Description.Value: The more you eat, the sweeter they become

Flavor.Value: Great when paired with Ambrosia
Even the mightiest of kings succumbs to illness.

Description.Value: Enemies fire an arrow when killed

Flavor.Value: These switches were invented to dissuade would be assassins from killing nobles. They worked some of the time.
A brew that stirs the drinker into a ferocious rage, making them dangerous to their enemies and themselves.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A key forged from molten rock

ExtendedFlavor.Value: After the last, unsuccessful expedition to the Golden Core it was ordered to be sealed off. An intricate lock was designed, and a key was forged by pouring molten rock into the tumbler. Tragically the key was lost by the engineers on their way out of the Shimmering Cavern.

Description.Value: Unlocks the entrance to the Golden Core

Flavor.Value: A molten key, always hot to the touch.

Description.Value: Average the number of held keys and bombs

Flavor.Value: Instantly reacts with iron, making it pliable without increasing its temperature.

Description.Value: Gain swing damage for each carried curse

Flavor.Value: Sword of the greater demon Zodd. It only grants its power to cursed individuals.

Description.Value: Enemies become hot to the touch

Flavor.Value: HW Flavor
Considered a luxury by the lowborn. The peasants of the salt mines don't seem to appreciate it though.
A very photogenic weapon.

Description.Value: Deal even more damage when you critical strike

Flavor.Value: This insatiable and eager beast approaches with a distinct and disturbing fuss.
"Discussions with the mirror are unwise." - Arkanos, the Archmage

Description.Value: Jump again in midair to land with authority

Flavor.Value: Lined with heavy iron and guaranteed to extend your vertical by two inches.

Description.Value: Goldsack Upgrade - Lose less gold on death

Flavor.Value: The iron spiders don't have as good a union as the others so many were made.

DeathFlavor.Value: Regrets investigating the statue.
Tangled with and lost to the tough skinned Gargoyle.

Description.Value: A creature that watches and waits

Flavor.Value: Gargoyles are patient creatures. They spend weeks at a time as stone statues, watching, and waiting for their prey. While in this state they quickly recover from wounds and are impervious to most types of attacks.

Description.Value: Goldsack Upgrade - Lose less gold on death

Flavor.Value: What good is hauling gold, if people don't know how rich it is making you?
The paladin Siegfried sacrificed his soul to Sho'guul for the salvation of his family and thus was forever cursed.

Description.Value: Ignore the effects of oil, poison, and electrified water

Flavor.Value: "The first galoshes were just two oily glomps strapped to your feet."

Description.Value: The peasant gains an additional potion slot
The peasant has the chance to find an additional potion in chests
The Spirit will occasionally drop another potion when a potion is drank

Flavor.Value: A tormented spirit that was found haunting a cask of wine.
Used by champion pickaxe tossers.

Description.Value: Feel the effects of a potion for longer

Flavor.Value: A sneaky little vessel with something left over for the new owner.
An ember, kicked from a bonfire in the depths of the UnderMine.

Beneath Ponzu's unbreakable scales are a layer of swift scales made of finer fibre. They are soft, pliable, and grant Ponzu incredible speed and accuracy for a creature his size.

When separated from Ponzu, winged scales use their fine fibres as wings, granting them and other scales flight.

Description.Value: Duplicate almost everything in the room

Flavor.Value: These kernels are ready to party.

Description.Value: Electrify your enemies when you pick up gold

Flavor.Value: Created with the golden entrails of a monster whose arrogance was unbound.
Bearberries are eaten in heavy quantities by the grizzled bears of the Rocky Woods before they hibernate for the winter.

Description.Value: Recovers a random amount of health

Flavor.Value: A healing potion created by an apprentice who hadn't quite perfected their craft.

Description.Value: Become immune to poison, if you can survive it

Flavor.Value: Tastes so foul, you'd swear it was brewed in a boot, and you'd be right.

Description.Value: If you have exactly 5 curses, removes 5 curses

Flavor.Value: A powerful potion that works under oddly specific conditions.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
"When something proves popular, saturate the market and make sure everyone grows tired of it." - Secrets to Success by Black Rabbit

Description.Value: Dramatically increases damage, but breaks when hit

Flavor.Value: The sharpest blade in the known world, but also the most fragile.
Complacency can turn that which is tough, hearty, and strong into something as delicate and fragile as an eggshell.
A ring passed down from generation to generation until it was lost by a careless child demon.

Description.Value: Puts out fires immediately, but requires water charges

Flavor.Value: Mining near the Golden Core required fire safety such as this blanket. Not a great sleep aid.

The Fire Thrower was invented in a joint effort between the kingdom's engineer guild and the arcane sanctum. A combination of human ingenuity and enchantment brings forth the pinnacle of dungeon security. These devices can distinguish between intruders, critters, and dungeon guards. They occasionally make mistakes, but at an acceptable threshold.
A pickaxe both made of, and designed to mine crystal. Figure that one out.

DeathFlavor.Value: Died of shame.

Description.Value: A holy companion that heals and harms

Flavor.Value:
Delvemore priests are trained at the Sanctum, a mystical building that contains all the secrets of the kingdom. Priests are taught various techniques ranging from healing their allies, to casting harsh light magic.

The priests of Delvemore are not considered the top of their discipline, but they are very polite.

Description.Value: Average the levels of all blessings

Flavor.Value: Peasants that don't diversify their skill sets often end up terminated. Killed that is.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A smooth stone resembling a key

ExtendedFlavor.Value: A curious object. For all anyone knows, the Shimmering Caverns have gone untouched by human hands, so why a key? Perhaps it was not forged, but instead created naturally. Created by the lapping of pond ripples against the sand over millennia.

Description.Value: Unlocks the entrance to the Shimmering Caverns

Flavor.Value: A mysterious expanse, left untouched by human hands

Description.Value: Increases swing size, but decreases swing damage

Flavor.Value: A common weapon in the Orcish army. Basic, but to the point.

Description.Value: Gain some more gold and health

Flavor.Value: Fish colored of gold belong in the sea, not in the belly.

Description.Value: Restores a large amount of health

Flavor.Value: Roasted to perfection. First verbally, and then physically.

Description.Value: Removes all curses, bombs, keys, and sets health to 1

Flavor.Value: To obtain absolution, one must purge themselves of all worldly attachments.
Elven riders go into battle on large cats. The glaive is their prefered weapon.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
A void in space that fires powerful bolts which seem to react to the velocity of attacks.

Description.Value: Decrease the amount of gold received

Flavor.Value: "Hasn't anyone told you it costs more to be poor?" - Black Rabbit

Description.Value: Adds a point of armor to the health bar

Flavor.Value: It is very difficult to wield a sword, or any other weapon without fingers.
Made from a black, glassy rock that is often associated with cursed objects.

Description.Value: Damage of a thrown pickaxe increases as it travels further

Flavor.Value: A heart wrapped in steel plate shall be pierced at great distance.

Description.Value: Deal more throw damage at low health

Flavor.Value: A simple metal choker inscribed with the crest of the hill troll tribe.
Preparation, training, and fortitude are not enough. One must be a combination of perfect and lucky to avoid catastrophe.

Description.Value: The Firebird will occasionally fire fireballs at enemies
Reduces incoming fire damage and both the Firebird and peasant deal increased fire damage
The duration of the ignite effect is increased for enemies

Flavor.Value: A legendary bird, worshiped as a demigod in the deserts to the far east.
It is easy to come between a fool and his gold. It is especially easy when the fool leaves the gold lying around.
Jangles pleasantly.
"You win some, you lose... a lot? Is that how it goes?" - Black Rabbit

DeathFlavor.Value: Punctured through the foot many times.
Peeped.

Description.Value: A subterranean creature with deadlier piercing attacks

Flavor.Value: Sand skulkers belong to the same genus as lurkers, but have evolved to burrow through sand and other soft surfaces. One would think that sand and softer surfaces would be easier to burrow through than earth and clay, but surprisingly, one would be wrong.

Description.Value: Goldsack Upgrade - Lose less gold on death

Flavor.Value: A pretty ordinary bag, but with one annoying hole in it.

Ponzu's teeth are wrapped in thin scales that exude poison, making for a ferocious bite. Sometimes these scales are shed while feeding, or attacking a victim, resulting in the toxic scale. These nasty creatures spread their toxicity to other scales.

DeathFlavor.Value: He was painfully electrocuted.
He now smells of burned hair.

Flavor.Value:
These giant mites are attracted to dark and damp places. It is a perfect breeding ground for their offspring. 

Lightning Mites build a static charge by rubbing their chitin together while walking. They can release this charge as a defense mechanism, electrifying their attacker with the strength of a lightning strike.

Description.Value: Gain maximum health when killing enemies

Flavor.Value: When logic and proportion have fallen sloppy dead, and the white knight is talking backwards.
Expands and then contracts the universal sticky force.

Description.Value: Deal more swing damage at low health

Flavor.Value: A necklace of gnarled orc fangs, caked in blood.
Very similar to the iron threaded garb, but slightly more stylish.
A whip is an impractical weapon. For example, it often hits enemies behind you as often as it does in front.

Description.Value: Restores a small amount of health

Flavor.Value: "Only a heathen would order meat well done." - Griswold, The Collector
A token of friendship between peasant and pest.

The Pilfer's body is extremely sticky, and surprisingly sweet, not unlike honey. Because of this, Pilfers will occasionally absorb items they come into contact with. 

Striking a Bomb Pilfer will dislodge the bomb, but the Pilfer will not thank you for the favor.
The head of the axe is actually a bronze dipped baby boot.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A key to Auduin's library

ExtendedFlavor.Value: Old rumors say that Auduin was a king fascinated by the dark arts and forbidden alchemy. It is no surprise that his library was hidden in the Halls of Din where few people could access it. Many of the books are mundane in nature, but others are rare, old, and contain many secrets.

Description.Value: Unlocks the door to Auduin's library

Flavor.Value: Only a few members of the King's court ever had access to the library.

Description.Value: Drop of Honey increases poison damage inflicted by the peasant or queen
Chance to lose a key when you take damage

Flavor.Value: The rest of the hands are dry. It is just the fingers that are sweaty.

Description.Value: An ogre with a hot touch

Flavor.Value: Ogres of the Golden Core have adapted to the heat and do not share a weakness to fire like their cousins. In fact, they embrace the flame and use it as their weapon.
A more mundane curse, settling for the simpler things.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
This chamber that greedily consumes any and all nearby nutrition, diverting it to the embryo inside.

The neutraily of goblins starts to come into question when looking at the noxious goblins. These devilish creatures have expanded their knowledge of engineering into alchemy and the results are terrible for everyone.
Skeletons litter all areas of the UnderMine. Men, women, and all sorts of other creatures have met their ends here. Other creatures have learned to use these resources to their advantage.
The lanterns, the torches, and the braziers watch on and they hunt with a fiery vengeance.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
A bundle of wicks, all cut short by a bombardier that lived dangerously.

DeathFlavor.Value: His ears were blown out by a sonic blast.

Description.Value: A flying bat with deadly sonic attacks

Flavor.Value: Nights in the Grimwood are long and sleepless, filled with the piercing cries of the Shrill Bat.

Bloatfly is a bit of a misnomer. They're actually regular flies pregnant with larvae eggs. The eggs are exceptionally poisonous, so eradication needs to be handled carefully. Occasionally peasants will be paid small bounties for the egg husks, as a way to cull the fly population in the mines.

Pontiffs are exceptionally experienced and high ranking members of the Sanctum and their conduct is shrouded in mystery. They seclude themselves from the rest of the organization and lead from afar. Some suspect they don't exist, and that higher ranking members use them as justification for unpopular acts. They do exist though, and their power is unquestionable.
Diamonds contribute nothing to the power, but they do make the explosion pretty.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A stone fragment depicting the Shadow Lord

ExtendedFlavor.Value: Noori is a special being that can phase between the known world and another world sometimes referred to as the Othermine. The Othermine takes on properties of the regular world, but twists them in a variety of ways. Noori's connection with the regular world is at its strongest when in the light. Darkness allows him to slip between the planes into the Othermine.

Description.Value: Health, damage, and healing become small and even

Flavor.Value: A powerful relic that restores balance and order to the world. Positive and negative become one.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A map to the Delvemore Dungeon

ExtendedFlavor.Value: Located at the bottom of the goldmine is a secret entrance to the dungeon of Delvemore Castle. This is the only entrance, and it has been assigned Guard Captain Toadvine and his partner, the priest Bathcat, as its guards. Many criminals from throughout the kingdom are locked away in the dungeon. For especially dangerous criminals, or those that commit acts that particularly upset the king, special subfloor cells have been constructed.

Description.Value: A map to the Delvemore Dungeon

Flavor.Value: A hooded figure appears in the corner.

Description.Value: The Djinn points out bombable walls for the peasant
The Djinn points out hidden staircases for the peasant
Every few rooms the Djinn will discover a treasure for the player
A cunning ally that sees through deception

Flavor.Value: Djinn are creatures that make the clouds their home. They are highly intelligent and have a devious sense of humor.
It is understandable to have a fear of spiders, if after a hard fought battle the reward is more spiders.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

Description.Value: Adds a bounty to a random enemy

Flavor.Value: Be fast, for time is gold.
The details of this ticket are hard to understand as they look to be poorly translated, but you get the idea.

DeathFlavor.Value: The last sound he heard was a terrible laugh.

Description.Value: A creature not even imagined in lore

Flavor.Value:
These creatures are completely unknown to the denizens of the Kingdom of Delvemore. No human has ever laid eyes on one... until now.  

Arkanos' peasants may rest peacefully knowing that they have accomplished at least one special thing in their lives, and that is witness the majesty of the Lucent Imps.
An aromatic oil that wards off harm in small doses.
The preferred explosive of the goblin sappers of the Misty Mountains.
A simple, but expertly crafted glass bottle. Perfectly suited to carrying brews of all types.
A common potion found in goblin logging camps.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

The common fly is far less dangerous than its cousin the spate fly. Flies have no defense mechanisms and mostly just fly in regular patterns. They also have incredibly short life spans. It doesn't pay to be a fly.

DeathFlavor.Value: Gently caressed to death.

Description.Value: An automaton with little to no intellect

Flavor.Value: Som was an archmage of Delvemore, but was expelled after repeated warnings from the Arcane Sanctum. Animation spells are forbidden throughout the kingdom, but Som could not help himself from studying the magic. He left the kingdom, building a small keep in the side of a bluff. He did this with the help of his creations. Som is long dead, but his golems continue to care for the keep, and some have wandered far beyond its walls.

Land mines are an outlawed device and are banned from being deployed in battle. Not only were they a cruel weapon, they left large swaths of land unusable by farmers depriving the kingdom of valuable, fertile land. Many years ago the remaining devices were stored deep underground and forgotten.
Douse yourself in a living flame that only has hunger for your enemies.
Metal studs make these leather gloves look badass.
An enchanted rune that was originally used to win trick shot competitions in the annual fair.

DeathFlavor.Value: Burned to a crisp.

Flavor.Value: "Well, now we have fireballs within fireballs." - The last words of an unknown peasant. Uttered during a tragic shaft fire. It left an entire subarea of the UnderMine inaccessible.
Curiosity and exploration can rejuvenate the soul.

In Delvemore it is not uncommon for lords and ladies to hire blackguard to assassinate their enemies. In some cases these rogues cross paths and meet one another on assignment. They are bound to fight to the death or risk having a contract put on their own heads. One blackguard in particular has reached mythological status, having killed dozens of his brethren. No one knows his name. He is simply referred to as the Nemesis.

Description.Value: Thrown pickaxe summons lightning on hit

Flavor.Value: A hammer comprised entirely of thorium. Grants the power and wrath of the gods.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A stolen crown

ExtendedFlavor.Value: One could command respect, lead with integrity, or just steal a crown. Some wouldn't know the difference.

Flavor.Value: One could command respect, lead with integrity, or just steal a crown. Some wouldn't know the difference.

Description.Value: A mother floater with omnidirectional attacks

Flavor.Value: It is only natural that this floating creature also be nicknamed after one of the famous bombsmiths. In this particular case it is a little more well deserved. Not only are the projectile patterns alike in Queen's Bomb and Fish, but Queen is a mother to both Bishop and Rook, as the Queen's Fish mother to Bishop's Fish and Rook's Fish.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

DeathFlavor.Value: Punctured through the foot many times.
Peeped.

Description.Value: A subterranean creature with deadly piercing attacks

Flavor.Value: Crypt Lurkers are a larger and more deadly cousin to the Lurker. They have more appendages and attempt to thwart their prey with a patterned attack.

Description.Value: Only one blessing is available at altars

Flavor.Value: The Djinn rolled his eyes as the fifteenth owner of the lamp wished for more wishes.

Description.Value: Heal when praying at an altar

Flavor.Value: Smells of sandalwood.
A thick, black oil consisting of venom from the kingdom's deadliest creatures. This poison acts quickly, reducing movement and inflicting pain.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A spicy mushroom with a kick

ExtendedFlavor.Value: Blastcaps grow very quickly once exposed to kinetic force. They are common in areas where earthquakes are frequent. Most blastcaps are extra spicy and the heat they exude is proportional to how fast they are chewed.

Description.Value: One of three mushrooms searched for by the Alchemist's Apprentice

Flavor.Value: A mushroom that enjoys a good jostle.
Made from the hardest and most valuable metal, so it's a pretty big deal.

Description.Value: More mimics than you would like

Flavor.Value: One's mind races and paranoia abounds, but is it paranoia when even the chests are out to get you?
In case of imminent danger curl up and form a ball. Step two, roll on away from that danger.
The dog of dogs. Strong, loyal, and above all else, fierce.

Description.Value: Installs a TRANSMUT3 into some shops

Flavor.Value: Dirk, the Alchemist discovered a way to turn blood into transmutagen. He sold his creation to the pilfers for an unknown amount.

Description.Value: Counter Weight Upgrade - Increases throw range

Flavor.Value: Constructed by the best engineers in the Delvemore Kingdom. Perfectly balanced, as all things should be.

Description.Value: Open locks for free, but for how long?

Flavor.Value: This thief's tool bears the engraving of a rabbit. Also, an engraving that reads "Black Rabbit's, hands off!" Further down it also reads "Seriously!"
Catching a case of the crumbles is clearly a cause for concern!
The moment Seer's tail was severed the creature set out a roar so fierce that rock shattered and iron was set ablaze.
Does not literally smash rocks, but it makes for a good name.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
In case a handsome mustache doesn't do the trick.
Very heavy and bound to bulk up the arms.

Description.Value: The Canary picks up gold for the peasant
Gold picked up by the Canary and the peasant is increased in value
The Canary gains speed and can steal gold from Pilfers

Flavor.Value: In a weird change of pace, this canary seems to outlive the miners it works with.

Description.Value: Kill all enemies and steal their health

Flavor.Value: Made with the blood of a succubus, which is incredibly hard to come by.

Description.Value: Start with an even more powerful random blessing

Flavor.Value: A holy relic, thought to be the original censer used by the god Din while he still walked the mortal plane.

ExplanationLocID.Value:
Lillyth teaches blessings for thorium. When a blessing is learned, you may use it on your next run. It will be lost when the peasant dies, but can be found again on subsequent runs.

You may learn more than one blessing, but can only use the first on your next run. All learned blessings can be found on future runs.

Flavor.Value: Studied with the Priestess
There is no secret to this potion. It is simply orc blood, extracted while under the influence of bloodlust. That doesn't make it easy to come by though.
Originally standard issue equipment for all peasants, but cutbacks were made.

Description.Value: A chance to not die, and no chance to break

Flavor.Value: "I don't know what you are talking about. This baby never breaks." - Black Rabbit

Description.Value: Goldsack Upgrade - Lose less gold on death

Flavor.Value: A sack made from the natural pouches of several beasts.
"Some say it's a disadvantage, I say 'there's no problem if you hit your target.'" - Gronk, Champion Pickaxe Thrower

Description.Value: Adds a point of armor to the health bar

Flavor.Value: It's common knowledge that the larger the shoulder pads, the more experienced the warrior.
"Just like mom used to bake." - Wayland

DeathFlavor.Value: Poisoned by a cooking vessel.
Melted by something like soup, but definitely not soup.

Description.Value: An animated cauldron, filled with caustic and poisonous slop

Flavor.Value: Do not hate this creature for what it is. Instead you must pity it. It was brought into this world against its will and must serve its master without conscience. Vilepots are simply another victim of the Drude witches coven.

Description.Value: Orbits the peasant and shocks enemies on contact

Flavor.Value: The orb has no preference on its owner. Its only desire is to orbit something.

Rook for many years experienced burglaries of his forge. He never reported them to the guard because he didn't want to reveal what he had been working on. 

It turns out the thieves were not men, but ogres... with a tasty appetite for destruction.

Description.Value: Transmute an item by hitting it

Flavor.Value: Get what you want through ingenuity, or sheer brute force.

Description.Value: Temporarily increases max health after eating food

Flavor.Value: Thin and soft and comfy, but with a few holes.
Wrix developed a potion that matches one's throwing form perfectly with that of the goblin bat riders of Urr.

Description.Value: The cost of Penance is doubled

Flavor.Value: Atonement begins with an earnest look at oneself and one's mistakes.
The Knight Toadvine defended his loyal companion against orders and was subsequently demoted to Guard Captain for his disobedience
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

DeathFlavor.Value: Had never seen a rat so large.
Felt the wrath of the mother rat.

Flavor.Value:
Rat communities are run by their matrons. These rats grow to enormous sizes and work together to take care of the weaker members of the pack. 

Rat Matrons inspire nearby rats to try their hardest, increasing their speed and damage.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
Named for the colorful light reflected by strong shells woven into the fabric.

Description.Value: Is whatever you need it to be

Flavor.Value: Dirk's crowning achievement as an alchemist. A potion so powerful the recipe needed to be divided amongst laboratories to keep it hidden.
Sweet and savory meet.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

Description.Value: Goldsack Upgrade - Lose less gold on death

Flavor.Value: Looks like it was cobbled together with whatever was lying around.

Description.Value: Deals damage and destroys rocks as well as other objects

Flavor.Value: There is a warning label affixed to the bottom that reads "Use under adult supervision."

Description.Value: Relics have a chance to be turned into potions

Flavor.Value: There is a good kind of mutation, and a bad kind. This is the bad kind.
"Explosive" can mean a lot of things, like being fast on foot, but here it is quite literal.
Many have wondered how the street urchin Olivia avoided meeting her end in the Crawl, a dangerous slum of the capital.

Description.Value: Sometimes drop a new key when using an old key

Flavor.Value: "Yes sir! This little doozy will copy any key you need." - Dibble, the Merchant
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
A king's surcoat that is more than ceremonial. Plated in thorium and impenetrable to daggers with ill intent.
An object used in prayer. The smoke it produces represents the spirit and will of the god Din.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
Toil is the act of trading health for something tangible.

Description.Value: Restores a moderate amount of health

Flavor.Value: A food imported from a far away island of paradise.

Description.Value: Gain even more gold and health

Flavor.Value: Not to be confused with a honey baked ham.
Alchemists of the Darkwood Laboratory successfully synthesized a medicine that makes one impervious to pain, but only temporarily.

Description.Value: Filled with the nastiest stuff in the kingdom

Flavor.Value: These barrels are filled with a dangerous, and highly flammable substance. Frequently used in the many wars Delvemore has waged against the Orc tribes. Over the years, they have been stored in random places and forgotten.

Description.Value: Leeches life from enemies slain by bombs

Flavor.Value: A cursed item, made with black powder and the blood of a lesser demon.
A deft hand and some quality string can save you a fortune in the end.

Description.Value: Possibly the same substance found in unstable barrels

Flavor.Value: The alchemist that invented the unnamed substance, found in the barrels throughout the kingdom was greatly rewarded for his achievement. Years after his death the same substance was discovered in the Shimmering Caverns. It turns out the alchemist may have been a fraud, but there is no denying the effectiveness of his discovery.

Description.Value: Increases stats and receive a blessing

Flavor.Value: Kings and Queens are anointed by the divine will, but Emperors... well they are the divine will.

DeathFlavor.Value: Pelted to death by a fly.
Destroyed by a tiny fly.

Description.Value: A fly with a dangerous ranged attack

Flavor.Value: Spate flies breed in dank, dark places, making the mines of Delvemore the perfect breeding ground. When agitated, spate flies will eject mucus covered shells to ward off aggressors. These shells can be ejected at surprisingly high velocity and can inflict severe damage to their targets.

Description.Value: The next time you would take damage, gain that much health instead

Flavor.Value: The most brutal axe cleave becomes a soothing bath of vitality in what can only be described as magic.

Description.Value: Some call it burned, others call it caramelized.

Flavor.Value: A food imported from a far away island of paradise.
A hollow crystal that traps moisture in its center, slowly converting it to a thick and viscous poison.
The first, unrefined versions were made by coastal trolls that would mix crushed turtle shells with their own blood.
"Seems there may be more than one cause to these quakes." - Unknown peasant
This tunic protected the alchemist Gordon during the catastrophe at the far away Black Mesa laboratory.
Magnetized metal has confounded even the greatest scholars.

Description.Value: Invulnerability to friendly bomb blasts and increases bomb damage

Flavor.Value: A ridiculous suit of armor that looks reminiscent of an onion.

Description.Value: Increases swing damage for each key you have

Flavor.Value: A sword in the shape of a dull key. Not practical as a key or a blade.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
This ring could never decide what it wanted to be, so now it's just okay at a couple of things.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A stone fragment depicting the Fire Queen

ExtendedFlavor.Value: Seer ruled the Golden Core with her brother, the Fire Lord Skortch, until he went missing. After Skortch's disappearance, Seer met with many challenges, including an adventurer that managed to sever her tail. Since then she has annihilated anything that has wandered into her lair at the heart of the world.

Flavor.Value: A hex used by Aevyn battle mages against invading paladins during the assault of their wooded homeland.

Will o' the Wisps are accursed beings of a bygone era. Their form has been reduced to a faint ember and they have lost all distinguishing traits. The only way these creatures can obtain peace is to unload their curse on another.

Description.Value: Pick up gold at a distance

Flavor.Value: One of Delvemore's largest gold vaults was once raided by a thief employing hundreds of these critters.

Description.Value: Get a bigger discount at Dibble's Emporium

Flavor.Value: So exclusive that there are only three members.

Description.Value: Increases critical strike chance for each carried curse

Flavor.Value: A dagger with a blade curled around like a helix. Doesn't appear to be a weapon suited for combat.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
Suitable attire for spelunking in dank caverns, exploring dusty tombs, and that's about it...

Description.Value: Thrown pickaxe penetrates enemies and objects

Flavor.Value: An easily concealed weapon employed by assassins of the eastern kingdoms.

Description.Value: All your relics are destroyed after defeating a boss

Flavor.Value: At each of life's milestones lies the opportunity to wipe the slate clean.

Description.Value: Lose maximum health when killing enemies

Flavor.Value: One makes you larger, and one makes you small.

Description.Value: Find old, gross food in chests

Flavor.Value: "Food in a chest is downright normal compared to storing a turkey in the wall." - Dungeon Chef

Description.Value: Take damage when picking up gold

Flavor.Value: Hot to the touch, as if they were plucked from the oven.
Some are blessed with intelligence, but that's not going to help you when staring down a raging Bobo.

A rift wurm was once captured in the goldmine. Many footmen were lost trying to subdue it, and it is still unknown why it strayed so close to the surface. 

When alchemists and arcane scholars analyzed it they found it had incredible regenerative properties. In fact, a rift wurm can lose any part of its body and continue on as normal. If the head is lost, the tail will regrow it.
A brindled and dark beast. Perfect camouflage for stalking your nightmares.

Description.Value: Adds a tent to the starting room of a floor, one use only

Flavor.Value: Sometimes, the best thing to do is just take a nap.
Peasants develop a strong constitution and thick skin as part of everyday life.

Description.Value: Increases experience gain for a familiar

Flavor.Value: Beltrame, as part of her apprenticeship, developed a treat loved by all small creatures.
"Despite all my rage, I'm still just a rat in a cage."
The wizard enchanted a second kernel, this one just slightly more golden in color.
A strange stone that radiates warmth and a sense of comfort.

Description.Value: Goldsack Upgrade - Lose less gold on death

Flavor.Value: Just a sack used for hauling potatoes.
Comes with cotton for the ears so they do not get blown out.
Channel the lust for blood. Aim it at an enemy. Destroy them entirely.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A stone fragment depicting the Sand Queen

ExtendedFlavor.Value: Selt guards the bottom of the goldmine. She spawns many larvae, but none ever reach maturity. She devours them before they can become rivals. Many years ago some dungeon guards wandered into her lair and were never seen from again.

Description.Value: Temporarily increases max health after eating food

Flavor.Value: Consume now, for the winter is long and the landscape desolate.
Peasants are accustomed to being hot and sweaty, but not like this.

Description.Value: Summon a doppelganger to work alongside you

Flavor.Value: Peasants would often use Doppelbock to sneak away for a quick nap with no one noticing their absence.
A sense of fragility clouds the mind, and it feels as if the lightest of impacts will break the body.

Description.Value: Soak up gold and get a discount at the shop

Flavor.Value: A token of friendship between the pilfers and peasants of Delvemore.

Description.Value: Restores a small amount of health

Flavor.Value: "Bleh!" - Griswold, the Collector

DeathFlavor.Value: The last sound he heard was a terrible laugh.
Burned to a crisp.

Flavor.Value:
For many centuries Imps were considered folklore. No one had ever seen one. At least, no one with any credibility. 

Since they are shrouded in mystery, even the mages of the Sanctum do not know their secrets. Where do they come from? Where did they get their magical abilities? Questions for another age.

Description.Value: Concealed in the cracks and crevices of walls

Flavor.Value: The pressure plates and arrow traps of the mines, dungeons, and even the halls were mostly put in place by the kingdom. Their original design was to discourage spelunking and tomb raiding. Of course, this made mining gold in the mines incredibly dangerous, but it was determined to be an acceptable risk.

ExplanationLocID.Value:
Baba brews potions for thorium. When a potion is brewed, you may take it with you on your next run. It can then be found again on subsequent runs. 

You may craft more than one potion at a time, but can only take the first on your next run. All brewed potions can be found on future runs.

Flavor.Value: Brewed at the Alchemist
An ordinary kernel of corn, enchanted by a wizard who thought it would be a fun party trick.
It is rumored that a wise and benevolent king erased half a kingdom with a snap of their fingers.
Age catches up with us all.
Warm and cozy gloves that keep you separated from the chilling touch of winter.

NoBlueprintLocID.Value: I have nothing to offer you

Flavor.Value: Sold by the Gatekeeper

Description.Value: Signals the entrance to the lost city

Flavor.Value:
Adventurers in search of the lost city near the Golden Core have all but given up hope. None return from the area. Either impaled or set aflame on the weapons of the gremlins that guard the way. 

At this point in time the return on investment is deemed too low. Even with unpaid labor.
Used in the honored past time of carving crude drawings in mine walls.

Trolls are part of the same family as ogres but have evolved highly regenerative blood. Their regenerative property even extends to their sweat, which alchemists have bottled for centuries as a cure-all.
Responsible for a whole generation of husbandless miner's wives.
Some tired cloth scraps, barely held together with failing string. Very breathable.
Named after a slow moving creature found in the jungles far to the south, this berry slows the metabolism of the eater.

Description.Value: Deal more throw damage at high health

Flavor.Value: Once a year an archery tournament is held in Delvemore. This pendant is the prize.
Queen taught her sons everything she knows, but they were schooled on alternating days.
A hollowed out paw that can be worn like a gross hand puppet.

Description.Value: Reduces swing damage and increases throw damage

Flavor.Value: A long blade of legend, wielded by the sister. What it lacked in power, it made up for in reach.

DeathFlavor.Value: Blown up.

Description.Value: A rat carrying an explosive barrel

Flavor.Value: Rats scrounge materials from all over the dungeons and caves and use them to build their nests. It is possible this rat mistook this barrel as such a material. Or, it is possible he knows exactly what he is doing.

DeathFlavor.Value: Regrets opening the chest with the teeth.
Knew in his heart opening the chest was a mistake.

Description.Value: A mimic with a taste for the finer things

Flavor.Value: Scholars can not agree on when they first appeared, but they do all agree that this is a new, never seen before, breed of mimic. Mimics were already incredibly dangerous creatures, but the problem worsens as they adopt new forms.

Description.Value: More skeletons than you would like

Flavor.Value: The adventurer's guide says that, in a pinch, items can be reclaimed from the dead. Sometimes though, the dead claim their own prize.
It's like you're wearing nothing at all.

DeathFlavor.Value: Impaled through the heart.

Description.Value: Guardians of a long rumored demon ruins

Flavor.Value: Ancient texts tell tales of a subterranean city lost to the ages. The city once  was the pinnacle of knowledge and technological advancement, but it was destroyed in a mysterious incident. Now the city is home to demons and evil creatures, or thought to be at least. No adventurer has returned from their investigation of the ruins. Gremlins patrol all the passageways leading to where the ruins should be, blocking the way.

Description.Value: Expand TRANSMUT3 installations to more shops

Flavor.Value: "Transmutation technology has proven popular and is ready to be rolled out to more locations." - Shop Keeper

Description.Value: Killing enemies with a bomb spawns two new bombs. Carried bombs decrease swing and throw damage.

Flavor.Value: A strange duplication device that attaches to any kind of bomb. Beware of side effects.
An important attribute for when the raging Bobo barrels over you.
To truly be deemed a rogue, one must rely on their wits, and their wits alone.

Description.Value: Temporarily reveals secret rooms, secret rooms can have secret rooms

Flavor.Value: An explorer's tool that reveals any and all secrets. That is if the explorer is quick.

Description.Value: A floater with ninety degree attacks

Flavor.Value: The original name for Rook's Fish was Ether Sail. They were given this name because of the way they float over the air, or as some would believe, the ether. Their projectiles are also a mystery, and many suspect ether is involved. As if the creature could concentrate it and use it as a weapon.
An ingenious inventor came to the faith late, and made the most of his second life.

Description.Value: Gold hits the floor with explosive force

Flavor.Value: A substance that combines with gold and force to create devastating effects.

Description.Value: Causes the maximum amount of trouble!

Flavor.Value: One mustn't worry about the small things, but it's hard to ignore them when they're this annoying.
An arrogant stone that disobeys the laws of thermodynamics.
An exceptionally hard to find potion, as there is only a single alchemist in the kingdom that knows its recipe.

ExtendedDescription.Value: The spawn of Matsutake

ExtendedFlavor.Value: These mushroom creatures may be one of the strangest in the Undermine. The largest among them have somehow learned the common language and can verbally communicate. The only thing that is known for sure, is that they want to travel as far as possible and take new root. As intelligent as they seem to be, they can't quite grasp other creatures being anything but other mushrooms.

Description.Value: One of three mushrooms searched for by the Alchemist's Apprentice

Flavor.Value: Eldest spawn of Matsutake.
Every wobbly step, every flinch of the arm worms its way into the brain and feeds a lack of confidence.
Wayland was asked to equip an expedition of peasants sent to the Golden Core. They didn't survive, but the boots did.
"The most sacred food item is the avocado. The second most is the lime." - Griswold, The Collector

Many of Selt's larvae will not grow into maturity. They are often victims of other creatures in the goldmine, or devoured by Selt herself. Despite being low on the food chain they can still defend themselves with sticky, silken projectiles.

Description.Value: Restores some health and can make you sick

Flavor.Value: Even cured ham has its limits.
Bishop was strong and independent. He left home at an early age after studying bomb smithing with his mother.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

Description.Value: Costs health to use a key

Flavor.Value: Peering through the keyhole reveals a colorful and twisting gateway into another realm.
The barbs are sharp and cruel. They dig into flesh and cloth alike.
A third enchanted kernel, dusted ever so gently in cayenne, salt, and black pepper.

A creature that builds complex machines can be considered intelligent, but what's more clever than stealing someone else's hard work and passing it off as your own?

Goblin scavengers stumbled upon caches of Dirk and Queen's old experiments, and with one small tweak have made them their own.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
Sometimes people hide things in a false bottom. There is only one way to know for sure.

Spiders found in Delvemore are nearly all poisonous, some more than others. The common, black spider's bite does not inflict a tremendous amount of pain, but it does partially paralyze its victim. Fortunately for the bitten, the venom has a short life in the bloodstream.
"Bombs were losing their excitement, and then this came along." - Bishop, the Bomb Smith

Description.Value: Throw a whirling blade of death

Flavor.Value: A tool that seems oddly good at cutting down trees, but what's it doing underground?
"Be prepared for any situation." - Norin, the Responsible

ExtendedDescription.Value: A key to the Delvemore Dungeon

ExtendedFlavor.Value: One dungeon key was lost to Selt's lair when some dungeon guards foolishly wandered near the Sand Pit. Another was lost to the rocky ceiling of the goldmine when Toadvine and Bathcat threw it at a spider they were trying to kill.

Description.Value: Unlocks the entrance to the Delvemore Dungeon

Flavor.Value: Enemies of the kingdom are kept in the dungeon. Entrance is prohibited.

Description.Value: Take damage for each of your potions, each room

Flavor.Value: An odd affliction that takes issue with bottle substances. Or is it the bottles themselves?

Description.Value: The Thunderbird will occasionally fire bolts of lightning at enemies
Reduces incoming lightning damage and both the Thunderbird and peasant deal increased lightning damage
Chained lightning from the peasant and Thunderbird bounce to more targets

Flavor.Value: During the rainy season, Thunderbirds bring storms to the highland plateau.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
It's not so much about bulking up, it's more about surviving winter.
The heart is willing, but the arms are weak and lifeless.
There is a price for everything, and that price can be increased.
Slowly burning calories and maintaining the effects of drinks can only be considered a blessing for a peasant.

Description.Value: Enemies drop gold when critically hit

Flavor.Value: "If you think about it, it's really an investment" - Black Rabbit during a particularly passionate sales pitch.
Ultra miniaturization and rapid enlargement are two critical fields of study in alchemy. They are both taught at the Arcane Sanctum.
The stone vibrates at such a frequency as to be mildly annoying.

Description.Value: Counter Weight Upgrade - Increases throw range

Flavor.Value: A complicated contraption that dynamically adjusts itself to maintain optimal balance in flight.
For prefered customers who have proven to have upstanding credit.
Completely impractical.
Pilfers have unusually long memories so try not to leave your debt for the next guy.

Description.Value: Start with a more powerful random blessing

Flavor.Value: It is widely believed that Din favors those that bestow him with the riches of the mortal world.
Upgrades the bomb from slightly dangerous to pretty dangerous.

Description.Value: Transmutes items in a small circle, but makes them fragile

Flavor.Value: Bends matter in a small area, but the process is incredibly strenuous.

Description.Value: Stock more items at Dibble's Emporium

Flavor.Value: Seems like a box that fell off the back of a wagon.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

Description.Value: A sign of friendship and cooperation

Flavor.Value: Bestowed by the Pilfer Queen to those who show compassion and empathy.
An ingenuity of war that isn't particularly effective against highly armored troops, but will rip through lightly armored ones.

Description.Value: Bombs brand enemies for sacrifice, +10 bombs
Deals damage and destroys rocks as well as other objects

Flavor.Value: There is a warning label affixed to the bottom that reads "Use under adult supervision."

Furnaces are used to heat the dungeons of Delvemore kingdom. Ingenious engineers use sluices to tap into the natural heat of the Golden Core, channeling it upwards. Many peasants were killed in the construction of the network, but frozen prisoners is on a sharp decline.
Allows the pickaxe to be thrown like a boomerang.

DeathFlavor.Value: Punctured through the foot many times.
Peeped.

Description.Value: A subterranean creature with deadly piercing attacks

Flavor.Value:
No one has actually seen a Lurker's entire body. It is thought that these creatures cling to the stalactites of huge caves and attack their victims from below. 

There are actually mining procedures for what to do in the case of a Lurker attack. You are to get to higher ground and pretend like the floor will kill you, because it quite literally will.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

Description.Value: All potions automatically drink on pickup

Flavor.Value: They say "a healthy life is one of moderation," but they also say "you only live once."

Description.Value: Duplicate all food in the room

Flavor.Value: A vial of well seasoned popcorn kernels. They vibrate with anticipation.
"The bite of cold penetrates the body entirely. A curse? No, this is a nightmare." - Unknown

Description.Value: Peep the names and health of your enemies

Flavor.Value: Typically unaffordable to peasants, but the mine's health plan partially covers the cost.

Description.Value: Leach the life of your enemies

Flavor.Value: The spirit of a selfish and vindictive king. He remains selfish and vindictive in death.

Description.Value: Pilfer shop items are instantly restocked

Flavor.Value: "Does debt wrap if it goes deep enough? Let's find out." - Dibble, prior to his infamous shopping spree

DeathFlavor.Value: Lost his ankle to a rat.
Death by one thousand tiny bites.
Knew he was already dead when he heard the squeak.

Description.Value: A slightly larger, but still basic critter

Flavor.Value: There is less competition for food in the deeper parts of the UnderMine. Rats tough enough to make their way into the dungeon have more opportunities to feed, which leads to bigger and tougher rats.
A larger, bronze hammer that tapers outward. Belonged to a disgraced executioner.

DeathFlavor.Value: Died of shame.

Description.Value: A holy companion that invigorates his allies

Flavor.Value: Delvemore Priests of the Sanctum are taught many techniques and many secrets. One of which can take an ally on the brink of collapse and invigorate them as if it were their best day on the battlefield.

Skeletons that bear the crimson color were once human like all animated skeletons of the UnderMine. However, their color is indicative of dark puppetry, carried out over millennia. 

The remains of these poor souls have been used to nefarious ends for so long that they have forgotten what it is to rest.

Description.Value: Increase attack damage and speed when killing enemies

Flavor.Value: Intimidate your enemies with dark lines and blacked out eye sockets. Or maybe just some cute whiskers?

Description.Value: The cost of penance at altars is reduced
The peasant receives a second level of a blessing when blessed

Flavor.Value: Sylphs are elusive creatures. It is rumored that they commune with the gods.
Rook learned bomb smithing from his mother, but always had a special relationship with his father.

Description.Value: Converts a portion of the peasants maximum health to two armor points
Enemies have a chance of dropping armor shards
Creates a devastating explosion when an armor point is lost

Flavor.Value: One of many fallen soldiers that have not yet made peace. It dons the same armor it wore in life.

Description.Value: Increases experience gain for a familiar

Flavor.Value: An egg, rumored to exist since before creation, births and nurtures fantastic creatures.
Clearing rocks is dangerous work.
An old prayer, spoken to old gods, grants blades the ability to cut down swaths of men. It works for pickaxes too.
Only worthy champions can find their way through the foggy woods where this weapon rests.

Description.Value: Enemies temporarily explode in arrows after a critical strike

Flavor.Value: A drawn arrow holds the energy to destroy its target. Guide it.

Description.Value: A ferocious cousin to the gentle Bobo

Flavor.Value: Scholars disagree on the Bobo family tree, mostly because a Throwbo ripped it from the ground and hurled it at them.

Description.Value: Temporarily consumes a future curse after praying

Flavor.Value: Also known as "The Altar." This constellation protects against bad omens, for a while.
Particularly useful after a hard day in the goldmine, or during a hard day in the goldmine.
Not particularly appetizing, but can buy something that is.
A morbid trinket picked off a prospector who lived way beyond his years.
"No colors anymore, I want them to turn black." - Yager, Priest of Din

Description.Value: Throw your pickaxe like a boomerang.

Flavor.Value: Now it is not just the spiders and the serpents you must be weary of, for all creatures carry fate in their fangs.

Description.Value: Gain a random favor, or a curse at the beginning of a floor
If the first wheel spin results in a curse, spin again
Spawns a relic if the peasant gains a curse, gains a blessing, heals damage, receives damage, and enters a secret room on a single floor
A child of the god Arengee

Flavor.Value: Chaos Spawn do not care for order. They have only one allegiance, and that is to entropy.
Derived by a straight-edge wizard that enjoyed ruining everyone's fun.
This ticket has no description. Just a crude picture of a key and a bomb with several gold pieces next to them.
"The bear is a symbol of power, strength, and overall badassery." - Toadvine, Guard Captain

Description.Value: A slime with a weak spot for gold

Flavor.Value:
"Pilfer" was originally a pejorative nickname given to these creatures, as they constantly attempted to steal gold mined by the peasants. 

There seems to be no end to them. They have become a constant in the gold mines and other parts of the UnderMine. It is unknown who the Pilfers serve or what they do with the gold they steal.

DeathFlavor.Value: Blown up by a sentient bomb.
Blown up.

Description.Value: An animated bomb with no place to go

Flavor.Value:
When the war between humans and orcs broke out, certain alchemists and mages were given permission to perform dark experiments.

Tickers were the result of experiments performed by a bomb smith named Queen, and an alchemist named Dirk. They were unstable though, and immediately detonated when provoked. Ultimately they were abandoned.
A simple, but expertly crafted glass bottle. Perfectly suited to carrying brews of all types.
A primitive but effective alloy weapon.

Description.Value: Detonate bombs when you feel like it

Flavor.Value: Provided increased safety to miners, but deemed too costly and an unnecessary expense by management.
Rats build their nests with whatever they can scavenge. Twigs, twine, the leather belts of fallen footmen, leaves, bones, apple cores, bits of metal, hay from the stables, other rats...

Description.Value: Reduces and redirects damage to your Max HP

Flavor.Value: A powerful defensive option that wears on the soul.
Torpor berries are taken on long journeys where food and drink may be scarce.
Looks to have been worn by someone else, but returned after it shrunk in water.

Description.Value: Recover health proportional to missing health

Flavor.Value: Peasants often drink something called miner's coffee. Brewed in a process you don't want to know.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A stone fragment depicting the Crystal Lord

ExtendedFlavor.Value: Ponzu, a hydra with an unknown amount of heads, sheds his scales constantly. These scales take on life and act as individual entities, but they remain networked with Ponzu and one another. They grant their strength to one another, and act in coordinated assaults. Battling Ponzu is terrible war of attrition that none seem to have the stamina for.

Flavor.Value: The best shield is one that lets you avoid the impact altogether.

Description.Value: Holds a bunch, but has a few holes in it.
A shield that blocks projectiles, most of the time

Flavor.Value: Skulls animated by some long dead necromancer.
Siegfried's shield, rid of its agonizing curse. Purified by a nameless wanderer. His legacy redeemed.

Description.Value: An ancient one, capable of summoning the dead

Flavor.Value:
When mages of any race practice dark arts for too long they run the risk of becoming a necromancer. All dark roads lead to this place. 

Once twisted into this form, necromancers learn that they have control over the dead. They summon the remains of all kinds of creatures, and use them for their nefarious purposes.
A spiteful curse that hungers for favor.
Carried by the priests of the sanctum, just in case.
Dropping any object into this shifting liquid will quickly mutate it into something familiar but different.

Description.Value: Chance to lose a bomb when you take damage

Flavor.Value: The first rule of transporting explosives is to make sure they are fastened securely.

Description.Value: Fire patches last for much longer and deal more damage

Flavor.Value: You might as well be walkin' on the sun.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

Description.Value: Restores not much health and can make you sick

Flavor.Value: Tastes a bit too fishy.
To be blessed by Din is to have deep pockets or know someone who does.
It's okay to be vulnerable, but not right now.

Description.Value: A dangerous master of the blade

Flavor.Value:
In the lowest part of the kingdom is a neighborhood called The Crawl. This is where the lowest of the low call their home. Even peasants look down on them. 

In the dark corners of The Crawl, scoundrels and thieves learn their craft. Their weapons of choice are short blades because they are easy to hide, but still very effective.
The prospector has always understood the true value of the earth.
Just enough cloth to prevent major blisters, but not minor.
Written on the side, next to a stencil of a rabbit it says "super cool supplies that were acquired very legally."

Greedy Pilfers are not content with a single nugget of gold. They need it all, and they need it now. These hefty creatures will elbow their way through a crowd until every last nugget of gold has been collected. Of course, that's just a saying. They don't actually have elbows.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
The most powerful bomb in all the eight kingdoms.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
Normally a healthy lifestyle makes for a healthy body, but peasants make due with what they got.

DeathFlavor.Value: Lost his ankle to a rat.
Death by one thousand tiny bites.
Knew he was already dead when he heard the squeak.

Flavor.Value:
Rats are found throughout the UnderMine in different forms. They are incredibly resilient and often carry dirt and disease.

One summer saw a particularly bountiful harvest in the kingdom of Delvemore. So much so that storehouses saw huge rat infestations. In the autumn, the rains came and so did the fleas, carried on the backs of the rats. The plague was so bad that the simple rat received the name Death's Messenger.
Named after the legendary fire lord, this rare rock is extremely hot to the touch.

Description.Value: Adds an indestructible curse on every floor

Flavor.Value: While his shield may be purified, the memory of the nightmare lives on.

Description.Value: Counter Weight Upgrade - Increases throw range

Flavor.Value: A premium counter weight, measured and engineered to 1/10th of a bit. The highest standard of quality.

Description.Value: Chance on hit to poison your enemies

Flavor.Value: A rare poison collected in the bogs of Moor.
A simple, but expertly crafted glass bottle. Perfectly suited to carrying brews of all types.
A curse that thirsts for power, but is left unsatisfied when it tastes it.

DeathFlavor.Value: His ears were blown out by a sonic blast.

Description.Value: Like a bat out of hell

Flavor.Value: Firebats originate from the Golden Core and spend their entire lives underground. They are coated in an ever enduring flame, and drip fiery droplets wherever they go.

Something about the Shimmering Caverns encourages things to develop points and spikes. This vine is no different. Fools that fall into these plants often swear that the plant moved, but there is no evidence to support this.
Brandood, champion pickaxe thrower of the hovels always said it wasn't about size, but a combination of speed and form.

Description.Value: Removes a curse after defeating enemies and stores it for later

DeathFlavor.Value: Suffocated after being covered tip to toe in oil.

Flavor.Value: Oil safety was taken a smidge more serious once it was discovered that they can come in pairs.

Land mines are an outlawed device and are banned from being deployed in battle. Not only were they a cruel weapon, they left large swaths of land unusable by farmers depriving the kingdom of valuable, fertile land. Many years ago the remaining devices were stored deep underground and forgotten.

Description.Value: Goldsack Upgrade - Lose less gold on death

Flavor.Value: Only one was made before the spiders went on strike due to poor work conditions.
A farmhouse style brew, with a clean taste and low alcohol content. Served as a clean source of hydration for peasants.

Description.Value: Transforms all relics in the room

Flavor.Value: It's unclear whether we will ever learn the secret of this ooze.

DeathFlavor.Value: Has been brought to justice.
Felt the burly arm of the law.

Description.Value: An honorable guardian of the Delvemore Kingdom

Flavor.Value:
Delvemore footmen are trained at the Kingdom's barracks where they are taught basic fighting skills. Footmen are taught to keep their shields raised in a defensive position.

The footman's heavy armor is effective at reducing physical damage. Iron, however, is an excellent conductor of electricity, making footmen vulnerable to lightning attacks.

Description.Value: Incredibly smart creatures, with a talent for scavenging

Flavor.Value:
Ogres, and their kind, are known to inhabit all parts of the UnderMine, but are incredibly good at concealing themselves. They are highly intelligent, and while they can not produce their own tools, they fully understand how to employ those of others. 

Ogres often scavenge bombs left behind by miners and use them for their own defense.

DeathFlavor.Value: Burned to a crisp.

Description.Value: A Glomp that has come into contact with fire

Flavor.Value: Oiled Glomps are not feared because of what they are, but what they can become. If an oiled Glomp comes into contact with fire, it is set ablaze and will ignite anything it comes into contact with.

ExtendedDescription.Value: A well worn and dirty book

ExtendedFlavor.Value: The title of the book seems to be "Creatures of the Undermine," but it is difficult to tell due to the book's poor condition. Written inside the cover is "Property of Arkanos, return to the library when finished." There is also a card slipped into a paper pouch. Four entries are written on the card that all read "Dibble," with four dates next to each. The dates all seem to be a week apart.

Flavor.Value: A tattered book with the name Arkanos written on the inside.
They come in many different varieties, but at the end of the day, they're just sharp objects embedded in the ground. Nothing fancy, but very reliable.
Just an ordinary chest used to deliver items.
Be careful, and most of all, maintain trust.

Description.Value: Adds a point of armor to the health bar

Flavor.Value: Comes with a complimentary breastplate stretcher for the more rotund wearer.

DeathFlavor.Value: Suffocated after being covered tip to toe in oil.

Description.Value: A Glomp that has come into contact with oil

Flavor.Value: Glomps were originally thought to be just water creatures, until an oil spill in the Delvemore mines revealed that these creatures quickly absorb elements in their environment. After this discovery, oil safety was taken more seriously, but only marginally.
A pullover made of linen.
The wear and tear from constant toil have left the hands bloody, broken, and riddled with pain.

Description.Value: What's a peasant without their trusty pickaxe?

Flavor.Value: A comforting force that ensures everything is where it needs to be.

Description.Value: Pick up items at a distance

Flavor.Value: Channel the powerful, sticky force. The same force that holds the cosmos together.
Blessed with a cut jawline and sinewy limbs, but cursed with the inability to maintain a buzz.

Description.Value: Shop costs are converted to health

Flavor.Value: The pilfers have grown tired of gold and now demand a greater sacrifice for their wares.

Description.Value: Chance on hit to chain lightning

Flavor.Value: "Bottling lightning isn't something you do twice, because it kills you." - Dirk, the Alchemist

ExtendedDescription.Value: A simple key, covered in dirt

ExtendedFlavor.Value: It is still a mystery how a simple creature like a Rockpile Mimic managed to fashion a cage out of railway tracks. It is an even larger mystery how it added a lock to its creation.

Description.Value: Seems to unlock a cage or a cell

Flavor.Value: An ordinary key covered in scratches, dirt, and mud.
Delvemore Wolf Spiders are found in the hills to the north where the climate is cooler. These spiders prey on larger animals and therefore are tougher and more poisonous than the common spider.

Description.Value: Increases damage, but decreases maximum health

Flavor.Value: You can only fire it once. If fired true at its target, another shot will not be necessary.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.
A drop of Selt's blood was used to synthesize a potion that can replicate her reproductive capabilities.

Description.Value: Become immune to fire damage and ignite yourself

Flavor.Value: Protects against physical burns, but not emotional ones.

Description.Value: Get some temporary bombs each room

Flavor.Value: A pocket of normal size, but enormous carrying capacity.

Goblins are devilishly clever creatures. They're capable of engineering complex machines, but they tend to use their power for entertainment more than anything. Chaotic neutral to the core. They also have poor eyesight and are easily startled. Approach with caution.

Description.Value: Oozes a vile and deadly poison

Flavor.Value: Secretion wurms are the result of thousands of years of evolution. Rift wurms made their way into the blighted bog, and slowly but surely adapted to their environment. They ingested various poison plants and slowly developed their own toxin. It oozes from their skin as they crawl along the ground.
A soothing nectar that feels cool to the touch. Good for burns, both physical and emotional.
The pains of time crawl through the bones, slowing the once quick reflexes of youth.
Nothing makes a hammer more effective than carving in some lightning bolts.

Description.Value: Discover more rooms and get rich

Flavor.Value: A golden idol of the god Din. Probably belongs in a museum.

DeathFlavor.Value: Has been brought to justice.

Flavor.Value: Crossbowman are trained alongside footmen at the barracks. Early in training recruits with an affinity for the bow are separated out and put on track to be trained with the crossbow. While the two weapons are not entirely the same, they share the guiding principle of: aim and fire at the thing you want dead.
Staring into the abyss, the mind races, the eyes grow bleary, and the knees weaken.
Miniature wizards miniaturized a shop and put it in a regular sized bottle.

Description.Value: Get a discount at Dibble's Emporium

Flavor.Value: Offers cheaper prices, free shipping, and two day delivery, but only within the Kingdom of Delvemore.
"In my version of the story, the hare wins." - Black Rabbit
It's quite easy to make two of something. You first take one of something, then you double it.
A crown bestowed to those that meet the challenge of the Othermine. Reverts back to its default state upon death.

Description.Value: Uncooked food is less effective and has a chance to poison

Flavor.Value: "We knew the food was tainted, but we had no other choice." Survivor of the Lingering Miasma
"You want to make sure your troll is hydrated if you're to extract the good stuff." - Dirk, the Alchemist
Spawned from a cursed object. This peril will fade, one way or another.
A tribe in the Storm Hills use a hunting technique that stuns animals with the force radiating from their arrows. Why they intentionally miss the animal is a mystery.
